data.title: Calculate x
data.solution:
import numpy as np

grid = []
for i in range(4):
    line = input()
    grid.append(list(line))
grid = np.array(grid)

while 'x' in grid:
    for num in range(4):
        row_string = ''.join(grid[num])
        if ('x' in row_string) and (row_string.count('.') + row_string.count('x') < 3):
            xi = row_string.find('x')
            x2,x1 = map(int,grid[num,xi-2:xi]) if xi > 1 else map(int,grid[num,xi+2:xi:-1])
            x = (x1 + x1 - x2 + 10)%10
            grid[num,xi] = x
        
        col_string = ''.join(grid[:,num])
        if 'x' in col_string and col_string.count('.')+col_string.count('x')<3:
            xi = col_string.find('x')
            x2,x1 = map(int,grid[xi-2:xi,num]) if xi > 1 else map(int,grid[xi+2:xi:-1,num])
            x = (x1 + x1 - x2 + 10)%10
            grid[xi,num] = x

for row in range(4):
    print(''.join(grid[row]))
data.statement:
In a 4x4 grid with digits and one or more {{x}}, fill every {{x}} based on the digits adjacent to it, so that
• all horizontally adjacent digits in the same row form a linear range of numbers, and
• all vertically adjacent digits in the same column form a linear range of numbers.

The common difference in each linear range of numbers may be any integer. For example, {{34x}} becomes {{345}} and {{x35}} becomes {{135}}.

Only digits 0-9 inclusive are used, but they can be considered as a cycle (after 9, continue with 0). For example: {{89x}}-->{{890}}.
data.constraints: For every {{x}}, there is exactly one solution.

data.outputDescription: <<4 lines>>: the input grid with every {{.}} unchanged, and every {{x}} replaced for the calculated value.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

In a 4x4 grid with digits and one or more x, fill every x based on the digits adjacent to it, so that
• all horizontally adjacent digits in the same row form a linear range of numbers, and
• all vertically adjacent digits in the same column form a linear range of numbers.

The common difference in each linear range of numbers may be any integer. For example, 34x becomes 345 and x35 becomes 135.

Only digits 0-9 inclusive are used, but they can be considered as a cycle (after 9, continue with 0). For example: 89x-->890.
Input
4 lines: four characters per line, either . (empty), a digit, or x.
Output
4 lines: the input grid with every . unchanged, and every x replaced for the calculated value.
Constraints
For every x, there is exactly one solution.
Example
Input
....
.34x
....
....
Output
....
.345
....
....
